definition: a piece of sawed lumber of little thickness and a length greatly exceeding its width
a surface, frame, or device for posting notices
examples: Pin the photo to the board.

definition: blackboard
examples: wrote the assignment on the board

definition: a flat usually rectangular piece of material (such as wood) designed for a special purpose: such as, surfboard, skateboard, springboard sense 1, skis
examples: … Tony Hawk has just legitimized the youthful rebellion they'd abandoned along with their boards.
Do a backflip off the board.

definition: backboard sense 1, a rebound in basketball
switchboard
a group of persons having managerial, supervisory, investigatory, or advisory powers, an examination given by an examining board
examples: She is on the bank's board of directors.

definition: league, association
daily meals especially when furnished for pay
examples: paid for her room and board

definition: a table spread with a meal
examples: offered to help clear the board

definition: a table at which a council or magistrates sit
the exposed hands of all the players in a stud poker game, an exposed dummy (see dummy entry 1 sense 2a) hand in bridge
table sense 1a
a sheet of insulating material carrying circuit elements and terminals so that it can be inserted in an electronic apparatus (such as a computer)
the low wall enclosing a hockey rink
message board sense 2
examples: Add a link to the board.

definition: cardboard
the stiff foundation piece for the side of a book cover
the side of a ship
stage sense 2a(2)
examples: one of the best actors that ever trod the boards

definition: a securities or commodities exchange (see exchange entry 1 sense 5a)
border, edge
so as to include or affect all classes or categories, in all areas or respects
examples: considered an average player across the board

definition: aboard
in support of a particular objective
examples: needed to get more senators on board for the bill to pass

definition: to go aboard (something, such as a ship, train, airplane, or bus)
to put aboard
to cover or seal off with a long, thin, and often narrow piece of sawed lumber : to cover or seal off with boards (see board entry 1 sense 1)
to provide with regular meals and often also lodging usually for compensation
examples: supplemented her income by boarding college students

definition: to check (a player) into the low wooden wall enclosing a hockey rink : to check (a player) into the boards (see board entry 1 sense 5)
to come up against or alongside (a ship) usually to attack
accost, address
examples: boarded me with some light remark

definition: to receive meals or lodging, to live at a boarding school
examples: bachelors who board at the inn

definition: to ride a skateboard, snowboard, etc.
examples: At 12, Danny joined his 16-year-old brother … on the slopes, boarding every day after school.

definition: to get into or onto a means of transportation (such as an airplane, bus, ship, etc.)
examples: A bit late, we hurried to the gate just in time to board.

definition: to put or allow passengers into or onto such a means of transportation
examples: … before my plane boarded I wandered into a duty-free shop to pick up a few last-minute presents.
